review_title: Awesome game, Solo is ruined by AI helm
one_reviews_text:
This game is absolutely amazing, to be in command of a Federation Starship is out of this world, and the system depth, (while at times not fully explained) is SUPERB. Aside from having to install the Ubisoft software to get it to start, I haven't had any technical issues either, although I haven't played online.

That being said, this is absolutely a game to play with a team. If I had a team of 3 people, this would be 10/5.

But, if you have to play in solo, your experience will be utterly ruined by the absolutely aweful helmsman. I was rescuing survivors of a space station, a Klingon bird of prey drops cloak, so I order my helmsman to approach the target. What does he do? He rams into the nearest asteriod, and sits there. I had to take over to get off the asteroid. Later, 2 more Klingon bird of preys drop cloak and attack. I destroy the first and helm is working fine. I order him to persue the second, aannndddd he sits there. He proceeded to sit there for the next 30 seconds making sure I couldn't get any shots off with my phasers. Just slightly pivoting left and right like he's riding a wave. There isn't even an obstacle in sight. I was manning tactical so I couldn't take over. Instead I just had to fire my torpedoes and try to interupt his targeting while my hull is collapsing around me thanks to my helmsman that didn't gradute high school let alone the academy. That was ONE mission. And that went relatively well. It's like this or worse on every single mission.

So I plan on buying another copy I can play with visiting friends on another computer because I love the game and am addicted, but the helmsman is ruining it.

If you have at least 2 people, this game is a MUST. If it's just you, stay away. It's awesome, but you're just going to get infuriated by Ensign GetLostAndRunIntoRocks.

review_title: Too many bugs - save your money
one_reviews_text:
My friends and I all bought the game to try to play as a team. We spent a few hours trying to get through the first mission. 

First of all, there are audio problems, as in during the game some people will not be able to hear selected other people. One person, the captain, count not hear anyone, even though two (not three) other players could hear her. Restarting the game fixed the problem, but meant we had to give up the mission.

Then, the controls for one player would stop working. In one run through, the tactical panel stopped being able to use the system interrupt feature (when it was required). When we restarted, in another run through, half way through the mission the helm offer station stopped working. No way to move the ship. We had two players leave the game, and then rejoin and swap roles, but that did not fix the problem.

It is impossible to complete a mission because of the bugs. Save your money until Ubisoft fixes the game (if ever).

I want to be fair, so here is my personal assessment.

Negatives:

1. Why can't we have exploratory missions, or anything without continuious life-and-limb circumstances? I'm so sick of the Klingon's or Borg showing up to try and kill me all the time. It's like this game was scripted by JJ Abrams.

2. Voice commands were working, and now they are not, and UPLAY support SUCKS! Without voice commands the game is not nearly as fun.

3. Star Trek based trophies for the Oculus home would be nice. Something to make the Oculus folks feel a little more special than the PS crowd.

4. Almost no substantial updates or improvements are made. And I have paid for one of them hoping things would get better. This is dissapointing considering the IP we are dealing with.

Pluses:

1. Good graphics. I like the bridge and crew renderings. I like the star fields, and the transitions to warp and impulse.
2. It's Star Trek (So you get a point for nostalgia)
3. I really enjoyed it when voice commands were working (And it isn't me. Even the game sees my mic test. It just won't carry over into gameplay)

Overall: Lots of potential, and a great IP with some really good exectution on roughly 60% of the game. But there are important issues that impact a truly favorable assessment. I don't honestly know that I would buy it again had I known then what I know now.

What do I mean by more?  More content, yes, although that's not all I'm talking about.  Star Trek has always gone against the grain as a storytelling adventure (particularly the first season of TNG) by pitting humans up against forces of nature.  Yes, there are villains and yes, there is combat, but quite often, the heroes are up against the elements and must work the problem to save lives.  An asteroid is hurtling toward a planet: go!  We who play this game have seen the show, seen the movies: shoot a torpedo at the thing, lock on tractor beam, extend a subspace field around it, technobabble the heck out of it.  I've always wanted to control a Federation vessel to solve distress calls with open-ended solutions and unexpected consequences.  Why have I not knocked off a star for this? Well, because that's a pretty tall order.  Most of my complaints are a bit cosmetic, really: the atmosphere is almost exclusivey new Abrams.  They included the retro Enterprise and a TNG Enterprise D is on the way, but it's a real shame the Star Trek I grew up with is an afterthought.  Long and short: it's a fun game and, like most VR games, woefully short.  If you don't want to be disappointed, try to hold out for $30 or less, $40 if you love Star Trek, or $50 if you're made of money.

review_title: A mile wide... and an inch deep
one_reviews_text:
Don't get me wrong: I spent a fair number of hours enjoying this title. My first missions I was full of awe as I was impressed with being on the deck with 3 other crew working closely together to complete missions. I had to rely heavily on every one of my  teammates to be successful, much more so than in any other genres I've played (MMO's, FPS, MOBAs, etc. where underperforming members can be more or less "carried"). If any one mate isn't performing, the mission can become very tricky (or, in some cases, impossible) to complete. This fact is one of the title's biggest strengths if you enjoy teamwork, but it can quickly become a source of great frustration if your Quick Match with a particularly difficult crew mate.

Given that this title relies so heavily on teamwork, I feel it is important to speak to the quality of the community. I found the community to generally be welcoming and friendly. Most are very enthusiastic about Star Trek (or Sci-Fi in general), and are willing to help and teach others so that they can enjoy the experience. The (rare) times I've had issues are 1) young children playing or 2) a teammate not taking things seriously (or sometimes taking them too seriously!)

My prime complaint is that the game begins to stale once you become familiar with the 4 roles. You'll likely quickly master the 3 "direct" roles: Engineer, Tactical, and Helm; then, for those that wish to take on a more leadership and decision-making position, I would recommend playing Captain. It is very helpful to have a keen understanding of the other 3 "direct" roles prior to being Captain so that you can give relevant and timely guidance to crew mates, particularly those that require or ask for more direction. But because there are few  story missions, and the procedurally generated missions aren't remarkably different from play-to-play, no PVP, even playing as Captain can begin to bland sooner than hoped.

Recommended, it's a novel experience, but more content is needed!

Game mechanics and playability are a 5 out of 5. Like many current VR titles, my only real disappointment is the lackluster graphics. A few games manage to do some amazing visuals but fail on the actual game - others like this have an amazing game mechanics but the visuals are a bit too cartoon like. 

Surface stuff like voices that often do not sync with the characters that are speaking just feels like the developer was being lazy.  It has a way of disconnecting the audience from feeling it was a realistic experience. Unfortunately, it just ends up reminding you that in fact none of this is real.

There are hard edges on a lot of the polygon models.  The planets and ships could look better with a revised method of lighting and texturing. Space is black - not dark navy blue. Everything, in general, is just too over-lit. Unity is capable of some great rendering and camera effects. There is no flaring of the lights, blooming of highlights, even some very very subtle chromatic aberration would help make the visuals feel a little more realistic. 

I have seen some amazing work done by rendering textures and environments using path tracers to pre-render global illumination to create textures that have all of the advanced lighting baked in then applying those textures to the real-time game engine models. It's low overhead and it produces great results. Ubisoft is normally really on point with the visuals on their AAA titles - I just don't know what happened here, especially given what a breakthrough experience this could have been.

review_title: A game that VR was made for!
one_reviews_text:
The concept is a 4-person crew, each playing in a shared vr spaceship, and each with a different job to do.. helm, tactical, engineering and captain.

This seems like a really difficult challenge, to make a satisfying game out of "ready photon torpedoes", or any of the other jobs of a starship. If the other guy is firing the phasers... is your job doing something different still fun and challenging?

The answer is yes!!! The game does a great job of balancing the tasks so nobody feels left out. It's INTENSELY satisfying to say "Warp vector plotted and ready on your mark, sir."

The fact that it's able to take technobabble from a 1960's tv show that is meant to be background chatter to story, and make it a convincing and even enjoyable set of tasks is kind of amazing.

That said, the heart of Trek is story... and this is a BIIIT more of a Tactical Simulator. You won't be talking to aliens to convince them to hold democratic elections. You WILL be launching photon torpedoes at their klingon butts and sending them back to Qo'noS with their tails between their legs.

This is an EXCELLENT social multi-player game. The ability to jump right in is fantastic, but even better with people you know. Each station is a different game, kind of, and each requires you to master different skills.

Also cool is that mistakes are costly... but a few aren't fatal, they just require everyone to think on their feet and work around the problem. It's not *oh, shoot, you forgot to raise shields in time... you're all dead!*. It's more *you forgot to raise shields in time, now your phasers are offline while repair crews are hard at work. Maybe limp off into a nebula and fix those while re-routing power to various subsystems.*

I hope they keep adding and adding new missions.
